Here is the code of ignore_sigpipe:
```c
static void
ignore_sigpipe (void)
{
  struct sigaction oldsig;
  struct sigaction sig;

  sig.sa_handler = &catcher;
  sigemptyset (&sig.sa_mask);
#ifdef SA_INTERRUPT
  sig.sa_flags = SA_INTERRUPT;  /* SunOS */
#else
  sig.sa_flags = SA_RESTART;
#endif
  if (0 != sigaction (SIGPIPE, &sig, &oldsig))
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to install SIGPIPE handler: %s\n", strerror (errno));
}
```

explanation: I selected all occurrences in the function that involve pointers or pointer-returning functions which could be relevant to Rule 8.13. Other parts of the code do not need investigation for this rule: - The local declarations ("struct sigaction oldsig;" and "struct sigaction sig;") are plain objects, not pointer declarations. - The use of &oldsig in the sigaction call is for an output parameter (old action) and must be non-const because sigaction writes to it. - The address of sig.sa_mask is passed to sigemptyset which modifies the mask, so that pointer cannot/should not be const. - The conditional compilation and assignments to sig.sa_flags are integer manipulations, not pointer issues. No other pointer usages appear in the function.
